Theme: Urban transformations in a globalising world

Cities are the most dominant social organisation in the world since the beginning of the twentieth century with more than half of the world’s population living in urban centres. This process will continue with astonishing speed during the next decades. Scientists believe that more than 70 per cent of the global population will be urban by the middle of the twenty-first century. A historical approach to recent and less recent urban transformations can help us to understand the impact of these changes. However, the urban form takes different shapes all over the world: the urban spread of Los Angeles is different from the dense living in Hong Kong’s skyscrapers or the historical centre in Amsterdam. This means that urban transformations need to be understood in their local context. The rising globalisation does not only remind us of the necessity to study the variety in urban configurations, but it also urges scientists to look at the growing diversity within cities. Our current global ages pose large challenges regarding inequality, political participation, social and cultural diversity, claims on public space, housing, environmental footprints, transport, energy consumption and health. This workshop allows students to study urban developments from a historical perspective.

<body>Urbanization has led to the enormous expansion of cities since the beginning of the 19th century. In 2012, UNICEF predicted that by 2050 more than 70 percent of the world population is likely to live in cities. In this module we will discuss various contemporary issues that characterize urban areas, such as gentrification, stigma, migration, digitalization, crime, deviance, and insecurity. Different research traditions in the field of urban studies will be applied to study these issues, thereby combining insights from disciplines such as criminology, sociology, and social geography. Students are expected to write an academic paper that includes a literature review on one more of these issues and a small empirical study. The goal of the course is to critically assess how various global processes shape the contemporary urban landscape.</body>

De jaarlijkse wedstrijd van de VAR (Verenging voor Bestuursrecht) bestaat uit het indienen van een beroepschrift en een verweerschrift en het geven van een pleidooi. Deelname aan dit vak vindt in teamverband plaats onder intensieve en persoonlijke begeleiding van deskundige medewerkers van de sectie bestuursrecht. Bij de eerste bijeenkomst wordt gestart met het bestuderen van de casus en komt het team tot een taakverdeling. Vervolgens worden data en tijdstippen voor verdere bijeenkomsten in overleg met de deelnemers besproken en vastgesteld. In de periode januari tot en met april doe je als team onderzoek ten behoeve van het opstellen van het beroepschrift (half maart) en het verweerschrift (half april). Van april tot aan de wedstrijddag staat het voorbereiden op het pleiten centraal. De pleitnotities worden geschreven en becommentarieerd en er vinden pleittrainingen plaats.

De inhoudelijke stof van het vak wordt bepaald door de casus van de pleitwedstrijd, die altijd meerdere formeel- en materieelrechtelijke aspecten bevat. Running a start-up requires operating under high uncertainty and navigating through often chaotic environments, where information may be scarce and unreliable. In this course, we will focus on the customer discovery process and address a set of skills that can help early-stage entrepreneurs with their opportunity pursuit. In particular, we will discuss the process of identifying one’s core business assumptions and engage in actively testing them by soliciting and analyzing potential customers’ feedback.
column2: In doing so, we will also discuss the role of leadership in this context, as well as the characteristics of highly-effective teams and explore how these can impact the performance, motivation and culture of the venture. Using a set of experiential tools, we will practice how to interview customers for maximum insight, how to effectively revise and update one’s business concept and how to generate commitment and traction for one’s idea. We will also focus on a range of influence tactics and negotiation techniques, which you can apply when testing for a product-market fit.
column3: The overall aim of the course is to provide scientifically grounded yet practical knowledge and skills that future entrepreneurs can apply when developing, testing and validating their hypotheses about a business opportunity.

Understanding what drives the valuation of companies is essential not only from an investor’s perspective but also in one’s role as a manager, security analyst or merger advisor. The primary goal of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary for performing discounted cashflow valuation of firms starting from first principles. This involves analyzing available accounting information, coming up with economically meaningful forecasts of future performance and incorporating the same as part of valuation models that are appropriate to the firm-specific context.

The first sessions of the course will focus on the adjustments necessary for identifying value relevant cashflows from reported earnings and other available accounting information. In the following sessions we will discuss how to identify the drivers of growth (as well as the limits thereof) to make economically meaningful forecasts. This will be followed by an estimation of the cost of capital for firms which involves among other things, the estimation of firms’ business and financial risk. Finally, we will learn how to incorporate these inputs into valuation models appropriate to the firm-specific context (for example, the cost of capital approach or the adjusted present value approach) to come up with an estimate of firm value.

To provide hands on experience, in the workshops we will apply the theories discussed each week to estimate different valuation inputs to complete a real-world valuation exercise by the end of the course.
• To obtain exposure to, and familiarity with, the financial statements of companies
• To be able to make requisite adjustments to financial statements for estimating value relevant cashflows
• To be able to forecast future cashflows, to determine the cost of capital, and to apply discounted cashflow valuation techniques appropriate to the context of the firm
• To understand the assumptions underlying the various valuation methodologies (discounted cashflow models, and valuation multiples) and the differences and the similarities therein
• To appreciate the role of judgment in financial accounting and analysis

As the population ages and treatment opportunities constantly increase, controlling costs while maintaining or improving quality is one of the major challenges in the health care sector. Value-based Health Care (VBHC) was introduced by Harvard Professor Michael Porter as a way to address this challenge. VBHC focuses on maximizing value for patients, with value defined as the health-related outcomes that matter to patients divided by the costs for achieving those outcomes. In order to optimize value, VBHC proposes a range of changes for healthcare systems, including changes to the way we organize healthcare delivery, the way we pay for it, and the way the system is regulated. While in theory VBHC sounds attractive and promising as a way to increase value in health care, it also subjected to critique. For example, some of the central aspects of VBHC such as pay-for-performance and shared decision-making have proven challenging to implement in practice. Outcome measures play a central role in VBHC, but several methodological issues should be taken.

into account when we want to compare providers based on outcome measurements. Nevertheless, worldwide the interest in VBHC has grown rapidly and encouraging healthcare providers to deliver high-value care has become a focal point in health policy. Also, in the Netherlands, many hospitals are trying to implement VBHC, and like elsewhere, they face several challenges. Financial incentives are seen as an essential element in stimulating health care providers to shift their focus from volume to value of care. Over the last decade, various types of value-based payment models have been proposed to replace common volume-based payment methods, also known as fee-for-service. Alternative payment models that (attempt to) stimulate providers to improve value come in many different flavors. And designing payment systems that stimulate value simultaneously is a major challenge. You will learn about the main drivers of value-based payment reform. In addition, by exploring applications of value-based payment in practice, you will learn about two main types that have recently emerged, namely pay-for-performance and bundled payment. The ultimate aim of this course is to make students familiar with VBHC in theory and in practice. By attending lectures and discussing the relevant literature and practical examples in working groups you will learn about VBHC, its advantages and disadvantages, and the challenges that lie ahead.
<body>Specifically, after this module students will be able to:
• Analyze the main concepts of VBHC theory.
<li>Apply the concept ‘Integrated Practice Unit (IPU)’ by comparing it to other forms of integrated care.&nbsp
• Demonstrate knowledge on the (dis)advantages and main methodological issues regarding benchmarking outcomes between health care providers.
• Explain the main drivers of provider payment reform in health care.
• Assess value-based payment initiatives and formulate future challenges.

This course in the value based health care track equips students with the knowledge and skills to apply state-of-the-art methods and systematic procedures for analyzing, improving, and making value-based decisions in healthcare. Students will critically reflect on the various aspects and trade-offs involved in value-based healthcare, while utilizing relevant theories, models, and concepts to generate suggestions for enhancing value-based services.

Understanding how to map costs in the care pathway will be a fundamental aspect of this course. Students will learn techniques and methodologies to identify and assess cost drivers within healthcare organizations and networks. Additionally, the course will build on the concept of care pathways, emphasizing the importance of modeling care pathways as a means to optimize value-based care delivery.

Additionally, the course will introduce students to systematic procedures for structuring and solving decision problems in value-based healthcare. They will learn to evaluate different options, consider multiple criteria, and make informed decisions that align with value-based principles.

The course emphasizes the development of critical thinking skills, encouraging students to utilize various models and perspectives to make informed decisions. While models serve as valuable tools, the course highlights the importance of not solely relying on them, but rather critically evaluating their limitations and applicability in diverse healthcare contexts. Students will examine the various levers available to adjust within a value-based service framework, promoting a systemic thinking approach that considers multiple stakeholders and perspectives.

• The student can critically reflect on the different aspects behind value-based healthcare and the trade-offs involved.

This course studies the values of culture based on the cultural economic perspective. In contrast to the conventional economic approach, the cultural economic perspective utilizes insight from both sociology and cultural studies to study the values of culture. We start from the fact that individuals and organisations in the cultural sector try to realize values beyond money and self-interest. One of the crucial resulting differences is that between the value and the price of cultural goods and services. We pay specific attention to the different spheres in which artistic activities are realized and analyse the different logics according to which these spheres operate. Topics that are discussed include valuation and valorisation of artistic activities, the notion of quality of cultural goods, the economy of attention, cultural entrepreneurship, and cultural goods as social goods.
You can clearly distinguish between the economic perspective and the cultural economic perspective.
You can identify and make sense of the different values people are seeking to realize in the cultural sector, and how these change over time.
You can distinguish and describe the most important spheres in which individuals and organizations seek to realize the values of culture.
You can analyse the different institutional logics of the spheres, and how these can give rise to conflicts about the relative importance of different values, and how they are best realized.
You can critically analyse and reflect on how a cultural organisation or entrepreneur seeks to realize the values of culture.</body>

Most people agree that, other things being equal, an individual has a reason to advance her own welfare. But what does this principle consist in, exactly? Does an individual’s welfare consist solely in a positive balance of pleasure over pain, or are there other, objectively valuable goods such as truth, knowledge and achievement? What about the welfare of others? Does an individual always have most reason to promote their own welfare such that self-sacrifice is irrational, for example? And what should we say about cases in which, by each promoting her own welfare, this makes things worse for everyone? Should the individual or the collective take priority here? And if the latter, then how do we choose principles which promote an appropriate distribution of welfare across various populations?

These questions will be amongst a set of question raised and assessed during the course. Throughout Values, Welfare and Cooperation, we will look at the basic rational and moral principles governing human decision-making and action. We look at the nature of value and welfare, and ask what does a good life consist in, exactly?

Whilst the course takes a theoretical lens to fundamental normative and evaluative issues, it raises practical questions, too. We look at large-scale collective action problems (like climate change) where each individual act seemingly makes no difference for the worse but together lead to collectively bad outcomes

Het vak Verantwoord Leiderschap in Organisaties, kortweg VLiO, wordt georganiseerd door het Business-Society Management departement en beschouwt business in een meer en meer globale wereld waar ondernemingen opereren in een complexe natuurlijke, sociale en economische omgeving. Van ondernemingen wordt verwacht dat ze zich verantwoordelijk gedragen richting hun stakeholders, zoals consumenten, aandeelhouders en Niet-Gouvernementele Organisaties (NGO’s), dat ze moreel juist handelen en duurzame ontwikkeling stimuleren. Deze hoge verwachtingen zijn uitdagend, maar creëren ook zakelijke mogelijkheden. In het bijzonder speelt het bedrijfsleven een sleutelrol in het realiseren van de duurzaamheidsdoelstellingen van de Verenigde Naties door het creëren van niet alleen economische waarde, maar ook ecologische en sociale waarde.

VLiO is bedoeld als een prikkelend en reflectief vak dat, geheel in lijn met de missie van RSM om een “force for positive change in the world” te zijn, de bijdrage aan de orde stelt van ondernemingen en hun managers aan zowel lokale als wereldwijde maatschappelijke problemen, zoals ongelijkheid, corruptie en klimaatverandering. Ofschoon bedrijven vaak een onderdeel zijn van deze problemen, bekijken we ook hoe ze onderdeel van de oplossing kunnen zijn. Studenten worden daarom aangemoedigd om na te denken over hoe bedrijven niet alleen waarde kunnen creëren voor aandeelhouders, maar ook voor andere stakeholders, inclusief de maatschappij in het algemeen.

Na de duurzaamheidsdoelstellingen van de VN als een overkoepelend raamwerk te hebben geïntroduceerd in College 1, bieden we in College 2 en 3 een brede inleiding tot de centrale concepten Duurzaamheid—welke een sleutelrol speelt in Workshop 1 —en Verantwoordelijkheid. Colleges 4 en 5, die centraal staan in Workshop 2, bekijken vervolgens hoe duurzaamheid en verantwoordelijkheid bedrijven in staat stellen voorbij ‘business as usual’ te gaan in domeinen zoals strategie en ondernemerschap, alsmede hoe dit helpt om de duurzaamheidsdoelstellingen te bereiken. College 6 introduceert het derde centrale concept in deze cursus, Ethiek, waar Workshop 3 vervolgens aan gewijd is.

De drie workshops die rondom deze colleges plaatsvinden richten zich, respectievelijk, op het ontwikkelen van duurzaamheidsleiderschap, het formuleren van een voorstel over maatschappelijk verantwoord ondernemen en het bediscussiëren van morele dilemma’s van managers met andere studenten. Via de workshops krijgt het cursusmateriaal dan ook een meer persoonlijke invulling, namelijk door dit te linken aan je persoonlijke ontwikkeling en je bewuster te maken van duurzaamheidsuitdagingen.

Om je verder te kunnen verdiepen in het cursusmateriaal zullen aanvullende filmmaterialen en animaties beschikbaar worden gemaakt. Ten slotte wordt na de colleges en workshops de essayopdracht georganiseerd.
Uitleggen welke rol bedrijven spelen in het creëren van en oplossingen vinden voor lokale en globale duurzaamheidsproblemen zoals corruptie, klimaatverandering en ongelijkheid.

Concepten en theorieën toepassen die relevant zijn voor hoe bedrijven kunnen en zouden moeten bijdragen aan het oplossen van deze problemen door zich intern op een bepaalde manier te organiseren en extern op een bepaalde manier met stakeholders om te gaan.
Verdedigen wat je standpunt is over hoe bedrijven kunnen bijdragen aan het oplossen van deze duurzaamheidsproblemen.
Een plan opstellen over hoe bedrijven kunnen bijdragen aan de oplossing van deze problemen.</body>

Een belangrijk kenmerk van veel hedendaagse bestuurlijke vraagstukken is dat zij de grenzen van verschillende organisaties, domeinen en sectoren doorkruisen. Naast deze complexiteit is het ook speelveld van sturende actoren pluriformer geworden en hebben traditionele instituties van de representatieve democratie aan gezag ingeboet. In de afgelopen jaren zien we daardoor in toenemende mate vormen van interactief bestuur ontstaan waarin overheden in interactie met maatschappelijke partijen, private partijen en burgers publieke besluitvorming of dienstverlening vormgeven. Geregeld ontstaat dit op initiatief van de overheid. Denk hierbij aan het organiseren van participatie in besluit- en beleidsvorming. Maar steeds vaker zien we ook dat maatschappelijke partijen, burgers en ondernemers zelf initiatieven ontwikkelen (zelforganisatie) binnen het publieke domein en daarbij al dan niet samenwerking met de overheid zoeken. Denk hierbij aan burgerinitiatieven, bewonersbedrijven en sociale ondernemingen. Tegelijkertijd spelen de organisatorische en institutionele grenzen die met interactief bestuur doorkruist worden nog steeds een belangrijke rol. Die staan soms op gespannen voet met vormen van interactief bestuur en inter-organisatorische samenwerking. Het managen van deze interactieve vormen van bestuur is daardoor een enorme uitdaging. Dit vak focust op de verbindende rol van individuen (micro perspectief) in het verbeteren en waarborgen van de legitimiteit en effectiviteit van grensoverschrijdend werken in de publieke sector.

Waar in vorige vakken kenmerken en theorieën van beleids- en sturingsvraagstukken zijn besproken op voornamelijk meso- en macro niveau, richt dit vak zich specifiek op het individu (micro-perspectief): verbindende personen in interactief bestuur. In het vak Sturing van Complexe Vraagstukken is de rol van boundary spanners al even aangestipt. Dit vak gaat daar dieper op in en onderzoekt de barrières en managementuitdagingen waarmee verbindende personen binnen verschillende vormen van interactief bestuur geconfronteerd worden. Zowel de skills, uitdagingen en strategieën van verbindende personen als de effectiviteit en legitimiteit van hun handelen staan centraal. Onderdeel van het vak zijn meerdere groepsopdrachten en een simulatie waarin studenten leren om een onderbouwd en concreet advies te geven aan managers die te maken hebben met interactieve bestuursprocessen.
Na afronding van het vak zijn studenten in staat:
- Om de complexiteit en achtergrond van verschillende vormen van interactief bestuur te doorgronden
- Om kritische voorwaarden te formuleren voor effectief en legitiem interactief bestuur
- Om uit te leggen wat verbindende personen kenmerkt en welke rol ze spelen in het managen van interactief bestuur
- Om barrières en managementuitdagingen van verschillende vormen van interactief bestuur te analyseren
- Om een onderbouwd en concreet advies te kunnen geven aan managers die te maken hebben met een specifiek interactief bestuursproces en/of project.

The continued growth of social media platforms, mobile devices and related cultural practices has contributed to a dramatic increase in the quantity of information that any individual or organisation can access. Citizens can use this information in an emerging cultural practice known as ‘digital vigilantism’ where they identify offensive behaviour and bring the offender to a kind of ‘online justice’ by making them visible through naming and shaming practices. These practices are manifest in digital and conventional media in multiple ways. For example:

• Citizens can make use of social media platforms (such as Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr) as well as social news sites (such as Reddit or Geenstijl) to shame other individuals, as well as share personal details about the target (‘doxing’).

• Citizens may also turn to online review platforms such as Amazon and Tripadvisor (or make use of review functions in Facebook or Google) to denounce and shame targets (for example, by leaving one-star reviews).
• News media (including broadsheets, tabloids, and online venues such as Huffington Post and BuzzFeed) may also provide coverage of these campaigns, augmenting the visibility of the incident.

These developments demand conceptual and empirical attention from emerging media scholars. Students will develop research questions for a small-scale empirical project addressing (aspects of) one of these focal points. They will make use of qualitative content analyses on a range of media data, including news reports, editorials, and other public data sources.
• State-of the art theory on the topic of surveillance, vigilantism and mediated shaming.
• Common research designs and methods to examine online denunciations.
• Design and execute a small scale empirical study on the topic of digital vigilantism.
• Report on their preliminary and conclusive research findings in oral and written form.

• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research, with an emphasis on challenges and opportunities associated with research on and through digital media platforms.

Onderwijs vervult een belangrijke rol in de maatschappij. Onderwijs is een ruim begrip, en er zijn uiteenlopende visies op wat er precies onder wordt verstaan. Door middel van onderwijs breng je ‘iets onder de aandacht van een ander’. Degene die onderwijs geeft, heeft daarmee een sturende functie.
column2: De onderwijswetenschap houdt zich bezig met de vraag naar de vorm, de inhoud, en het beoogde resultaat van die sturing, alsmede de visie van waaruit onderwijs wordt gegeven. In het vak ‘Visies op onderwijs en leren’ richten we ons op een van de centrale aspecten van onderwijs, namelijk het leren en het lesgeven.&nbsp

column1: Leren doen we altijd en overal en speelt een cruciale rol in het leven van ieder individu. We leren in informele settings, gedreven door nieuwsgierigheid en via imitatie en trial en error, maar ook meer formeel, door het onderwijs dat we volgen of in professionele situaties via training en cursussen. Leren blijft ons hele leven belangrijk voor onze ontwikkeling en onderwijs is erop gericht om ons leren via een degelijk curriculum en gerichte instructie zo goed mogelijk te faciliteren. Maar wat is leren eigenlijk en hoe kan instructie het beste worden vormgegeven? Welke factoren spelen een rol in het ontwerpen van onderwijsonderdelen? Onderwijswetenschappers houden zich bij uitstek bezig met de kwaliteit van onderwijs en onderwijsinstellingen en van het leren dat daar plaatsvindt. Ook houden zij zich bezig met het ontwerpen van trainingen en lesmethodes, of het adviseren van gemeentes of de overheid.

In het vak ‘Visies op onderwijs en leren’ maken studenten kennis met het brede onderwijswetenschappelijke vakgebied aan de hand van relevante en eigentijdse onderwijsvraagstukken. Verschillende onderwijswetenschappelijke theorieën over leren en onderwijs komen aan bod, evenals het leren van het individu en het leren in context, zoals in interactie met de leerkracht of technologie. Studenten maken daarnaast kennis met de praktijk van het lesontwerpen en schrijven van advies op basis van wetenschappelijk onderbouwde analyse en kritische reflectie. Dit doen zij in opdracht van de grootstedelijke onderwijspraktijk en (gedeeltelijk) samen met medestudenten. The first part of the course examines the nature of cooperation. It examines the contributions to the study of cooperation that have been made not only by economists, but also by psychologists, evolutionary biologists and to some extent sociologists. Emphasis will be given to the methodological issues facing economists and psychologists who study cooperation in laboratory settings.
What is the best definition of cooperation, and how does the concept of cooperation relate to the concept of altruism and of selfishness?

What is the psychological mechanism that disposes individuals to cooperate with each other? For example, is cooperation the result of individuals being disposed to learn and follow social norms? or the result of individuals having other-regarding preferences? or is there a game-theoretic explanation of cooperation that only needs to posit selfish preferences?
How do these psychological explanations relate to “evolutionary” explanations of cooperation? For example, explanations that appeal to&nbsp
column3: natural selection operating on genetic variation inherited from one’ biological parents?

By the end of this course, students can:

3) Critically assess the key evidence from behavioural economics / psychology that bears on questions of cooperation, in light of the issues of both internal and external validity.

4) Assess the strengths and weakness of the three major approaches to welfare (preference based, objective list, and happiness), drawing on their understanding of cooperation gained in the first half of the course.</body>

The course offers an introduction to Freudian and post-Freudian psychoanalysis. The aim, however, is not to introduce the student to psychoanalytic therapy, but to examine the consequences of psychoanalysis for the philosophical concepts of the subject and truth. In other words, we will study psychoanalysis as philosophy. The point of departure: a subject is not what you think it is. That is, the subject is not the bearer of consciousness and the 'I' is not the initiator of his thoughts and actions. The psychoanalytic concept of the unconscious plays a crucial role here. Freud distinguishes the Ego from the Id and the Superego. Moreover, already with Freud, it becomes clear that the subject is always a speaking subject. Through language, the subject tries to keep itself together. The subject uses language not only to reveal the truth but also to conceal it. No wonder that psychoanalysis, in contrast to rationalist philosophy, is especially interested in where the subject loses control over its speaking, as happens, for instance, in the slip of the tongue.

The main part of the course will be devoted to the impact of Freud's thinking on the work of Jacques Lacan. We will closely read some texts and discuss the famous 'graph of desire', which offers an overview of the Lacanian doctrine. We will elaborate on Lacan's principles that 'desire is always desire of the Other' and 'the unconscious is structured like a language'. We will look at Lacan's particular 'grammar', and his use of formulas and graphs.

We will also discuss contemporary psychoanalytical thinkers such as Julia Kristeva and Slavoj Žižek. Kristeva leaves the male-oriented analysis of Freud and Lacan behind. We will discuss her notion of abjection. Attention will also be paid to the effect of Lacanian psychoanalysis in the work of Slavoj Žižek. An important place in the course is given to art and literature: psychoanalysis proves time and again to be an excellent way of learning to interpret art, literature or film. The student will be challenged to do so in several assignments. One of the main goals of the course is to learn to read the often unruly texts of psychoanalysis and Lacan in particular. Besides 2 assignments, the student concludes the course with a small essay.</body>

Can read and comment upon some core texts in the psychoanalytical tradition.
Can apply the concepts of psychoanalysis to analyze works of literature, art, poetry, and/or film.
Can critically evaluate the psychoanalytical notions philosophically. That is to say, the student is able to clearify the philosophical bearings of psychoanalysis.</body>

In 1993 an international pleading competition for law students was launched known as the Willem C. Vis Moot (Vis Moot). The main subject matter of the moot arbitration are the Vienna Convention on the International Sale of Goods (CISG) and international arbitration. Very quickly, the Vis Moot has grown from a competition between 11 university teams in the first year to a competition that attracts close to 400 teams from all around the world (for further information please see http://www.cisg.law.pace.edu/vis.html).

From the beginning, teams of Erasmus School of Law (ESL) have competed in the Vis Moot. The competition itself is held each year in the week before Easter in Vienna, Austria. In preparation for Vienna, each team must write a memorandum for the claimant and a memorandum for the respondent. As these memoranda are due by the end of November, respectively in January, the team will be preparing for the moot arbitration from early October until April.

This elective course gives the students a unique opportunity to put their legal and advocacy skills in practice. During the course, students will work on the fictional case concerning the international sale of goods. While working on the case file, students will be required to develop legal argumentation and to prepare legal briefs introducing position of claimant and respondent in a dispute that arose from the unsuccessful cross-border transaction. At the later stage, students will also need to advocate in favor of their position before the arbitral tribunal.

All the preparations are done under careful supervision of teachers of the Erasmus School of Law and with support of external lawyers active in international arbitration. Students will have a chance to test their ideas and persuasive skills during numerous pleading sessions both at the university, at the law firms and even abroad (pre-moots). Finally, the students will have a chance to challenge themselves when stepping in the shoes of claimant and respondent during the actual Vis moot in Vienna.

Deze cursus legt de basis voor de kwantitatieve vakken in het Bedrijfskunde curriculum.

De wetenschappelijke beschrijving en analyse van complexe bedrijfskundige problemen vragen vaak om een analytische aanpak. Vaak is een expliciete beschrijving van een verandering in een systeem nodig als het van de ene staat naar een andere staat veranderd. Wiskunde kan helpen bij het beschrijven van essentiële elementen van zulke veranderingen. Het woord ‘model’ wordt vaak gebruikt voor een kwantitatieve beschrijving van een specifiek probleem waarin een systeem zich bevindt op elk moment in de tijd. Het werken met modellen komt regelmatig terug tijdens de studie bedrijfskunde. Het proces om een model te bouwen en te analyseren vraagt om een wiskundige manier van denken. Daarom zijn wiskundige vaardigheden cruciaal om succesvol met deze modellen om te gaan.

New technologies, artificial intelligence, platform workers, digitalization, flexibilization: The digital age has seen unprecedented changes and has led to a virtually new world of work. Such revolutionary changes, though, do not signify changes only for organizations, employers and the market. They also signify a new workplace for individual workers. For instance, the flexibilization of work and the implementation of new technologies seem to fundamentally change people’s working conditions and their quality of working life. Self-employed micro entrepreneurs rely on smartphone APPs with smart algorithms to receive work tasks and income. Similarly, employees increasingly work in virtual teams and use remote networking technology to connect and interact with others.

In the current course, building and extending on prior knowledge about the macro-level, we will particularly focus on the micro-level of organizational behaviour in the digital age. In other words, we will examine how individual work behaviours manifest within and are influenced by the context of the digital age.

What consequences does the new way of working of the digital age has for work behaviours, motivation, well-being and performance? How can workers regulate their behaviours so as to deal with this context successfully? And, to go one step further, how can workers make the best of this new context and maximize their performance and their personal wellbeing?

Students are invited to use frameworks and theories from organizational psychology, management studies and sociology in order to understand, analyse and critically evaluate the implications of the digital age for individual work behaviours. The course will consist of lectures, working groups and seminars with international experts. Furthermore, through the practical group assignment of this course, students will be invited to apply what they have learnt in practice, either by diagnosing a real-life problem (e.g., via data collection) or by proposing an intervention that workers/organizations may apply in practice.
1. Theoretical and empirical knowledge and (multi-disciplinary) insights into the implications of the digital age for individual work behaviours.
2. Reflect upon and engage critically with perspectives addressing the consequences (positive or negative) that the digital age may have for individual workers.
3. Knowledge and insights into strategies workers can use so as to deal with or maximize the positive consequences of the new way of working within the context of the digital age.
4. Evaluate case studies and diagnose “problems” that workers undergo in practice (e.g., in real-life organizations) in the face of the digital age.
5. Apply knowledge in practice and present interventions that organizations/workers can use in order to maximize their well-being or performance in the context of the digital age.</body>

This workshop is divided into two parts: Sustainable Finance and Business Ethics.

The Sustainable Finance part starts with a brief overview of the state of sustainable finance, both in terms of the nascent academic literature and its application in asset management. Next, the link between sustainability and finance is illustrated using a live case study. With a list of questions, it is shown how to integrate sustainability into investment analysis by connecting sustainability to business models, competitive position, strategy and value drivers. This allows the analyst to assess the transition preparedness of a company and to determine its resulting value. A comparison is made to similar case studies. For example, we consider the case of McDonald’s, a company that faces substantial sustainability challenges, on both the social (health) and environmental (footprint) dimensions. Our findings suggest that McDonald’s is not as well positioned as Philips, but much better than Air France-KLM. Unlike the latter, McDonald’s does have significant options to deal with its sustainability issues.

The Business Ethics part starts with a brief overview of the CFA Institute’s Code of Ethics and Standards of Professional Conduct, which serve as an ethical benchmark for investment professionals around the globe. In the following, we will discuss difficulties and ethical dilemmas that can occur in day-to-day activities of investment professionals. Next, several real-world cases of unethical and/or unprofessional behaviour of market participants will be presented. In this context, we will also look at the potentially devastating consequences of these types of behaviour in financial markets. Finally, we will go through a series of case studies regarding ethical behaviour and professional conducted provided by the CFA Institute. Participants will work on a set of questions and solutions will be discussed thereafter.
• Describe the challenges and limitations of financial theory and practice in addressing and accounting for sustainability issues
• Analyze a company in terms of the externalities and other sustainability challenges it faces, and link those to the valuation of the company
• Understand the key cornerstones of ethical and professional behaviour for investment professionals as well as the importance of business ethics
• Apply the concepts of the CFA Institute’s Code of Ethics and Standards of Professional Conduct to real-world cases and derive recommended course of action

We tend to think about empires as a thing of the past, as something with little to no relevance to current world politics – but is that so? How can we explain the racial conflict underpinning Black Lives Matter, the under-representation of the Global South in the UN Security Council, or US military interventions in Iraq and Afghanistan? This course explores the post-1945 legacies of empire in a world formally organized around sovereign independence. How, where and in which forms did the material, ideational and organizational principles of empire bleed into our current system of sovereign equality? This course will explore topics such as race and the global colour line, the UN system and global governance, as well as the relation between war, security and Orientalism. In doing so, it will provide you with an understanding of the following three core themes: 1) the interplay between material, ideational and organizational elements in shaping international relations, 2) the tension between imperial hierarchy and sovereign equality as organizing principles of world politics, and 3) the intersecting logics of decolonization, the global Cold War and American hegemony in transforming world order. This is an essay-based and reading-intensive elective requiring active participation.

By the end of this module, students can explain and analyse the core concept of ‘empire’. They can identify historical legacies of empire in world politics and critically assess the relation between imperial hierarchy and sovereign equality particularly as it intersects with the logics of decolonization, Global Cold War dynamics and post-1945 American hegemony. Finally, students will be able to reflect on the limits and possibilities of understanding current world order through the lens of empire.

In dit vak komen de in de praktijk meest frequent gebruikte en belangrijkste zekerheden aan bod: pand, hypotheek, eigendomsvoorbehoud, bankgarantie, borgtocht en hoofdelijkheid. Dat gebeurt niet enkel door hun juridisch regime te bestuderen, maar ook door te kijken naar hoe deze zekerheden in de praktijk fungeren en gedijen. Wanneer wordt het beste voor welke zekerheid gekozen? Met welke aandachtspunten moet bij elk van deze zekerheden rekening worden gehouden? Hoe sterk is de zekerheid die deze zekerheden bieden precies?

Deze laatste vraag is in het bijzonder relevant in situaties van insolventie, in het bijzonder faillissement, dat vaak de lakmoesproef van het zekerhedenrecht wordt genoemd. Daarom wordt in dit vak, onder meer door een advocaat, bankjurist, (voormalig) curator en rechter-commissaris, stilgestaan bij het lot van zekerheden in faillissement, met beantwoording van essentiële vragen zoals: welke positie hebben schuldeisers met zekerheden? In welke mate kan hun positie worden aangetast door de curator? En hoe kan de curator optreden in geval van benadeling van schuldeisers? Niet alleen wordt aandacht besteed aan zekerheden en faillissement, maar ook aan het vermijden van faillissementen, en meer bepaald het reorganiseren of doorstarten van een onderneming in moeilijkheden. Concreet gebeurt dit door onder meer de kernpunten van de Wet Homologatie Onderhands Akkoord (WHOA) door een praktijkgerichte bril te bekijken.</body>

Gezondheidszorg is een complex beleidsdomein waarin publieke, private en professionele belangen door elkaar lopen. Dit leidt soms tot lastige vraagstukken, zoals: Wat is de beste balans tussen individuele en collectieve verantwoordelijkheden, tussen collectieve en private financiering, tussen publieke en private uitvoering, tussen samenwerking en concurrentie, en tussen nationaal en gedecentraliseerd beleid? Het antwoord op deze vragen, zo zullen we zien, verschilt naar gelang de context en het gehanteerde perspectief. Zo kan het er anders uit zien voor de ziekenhuiszorg dan voor de jeugdzorg, en treden verschuivingen op in de tijd.

In dit vak krijgen studenten de kennis en vaardigheden aangereikt die nodig zijn om bovengenoemde vraagstukken te begrijpen en analyseren, en om mee te denken over de inrichting, organisatie en financiering van het Nederlandse zorgstelsel. Dit vraagt om een multidisciplinaire aanpak met gedachtegoed vanuit de bestuurskundige, juridische en economische wetenschappen.

Tijdens interactieve colleges en werkgroepen worden studenten uitgedaagd om relevante concepten en theorieën toe te passen op concrete vraagstukken in verschillende domeinen van de Nederlandse gezondheidszorg zoals de curatieve zorg, langdurige zorg, jeugdzorg en maatschappelijke ondersteuning. Bijzondere aandacht gaat uit naar de rol van zorgverzekeraars in het Nederlandse zorgstelsel, en naar de rol van de (centrale en decentrale) overheid en die van toezichthouders.

• Het kunnen analyseren van actuele beleidsvraagstukken ten aanzien van de inrichting, organisatie en financiering van de Nederlandse gezondheidszorg met gebruik van bestuurskundige, juridische en economische concepten en theorieën.

• Het kunnen schrijven van een individueel essay over een beleidsvraagstuk ten aanzien van de inrichting, organisatie en/of financiering van de Nederlandse gezondheidszorg met een multidisciplinaire beschouwing van bestuurskundige, juridische en/of economische aspecten.
